learning_outcomes.description: Describe the role of research and evaluation in informing ethical and effective social work practice within broader social, cultural, and policy contexts.
Explain the stages of the social work research process, from identifying an issue to disseminating findings, including the use of various research approaches.
Critically review and synthesise existing qualitative and quantitative social work research, identifying useful evidence, gaps and appropriate research questions.
Select and justify appropriate and ethical research designs and sampling techniques to address identified knowledge gaps in a social work context.
Select and adapt research dissemination strategies that are audience-appropriate and capable of influencing social work practice and policy.

assessments.weighting: <dd>20% each quiz worth 4%; best 5 out of 6 quizzes included in count. </dd>

assessments.task_description:
In weeks 1-6, each week you will undertake a brief (10 minute; 3-4 questions) in-person quiz during the workshop. Each quiz is worth 4% of your final grade.

The best 5 of these 6 quizzes will count towards your mark out of 20.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This description is only a summary of the task. For full details, including the marking rubric, please refer to the course Learn UQ (Blackboard) site.

Rationale

The Australian Association of Social Workers (AASW) Practice Standards (2023) require social workers to “practice within a professional knowledge framework informed by a critical understanding of contemporary social work theory and research” (Standard 5) and to “be active learners, open to new and emerging knowledge, research and evidence informing their practice” (Standard 9).

However, evidence suggests that social work practitioners report a lack of confidence in research knowledge and skills (DeFaia, 2015) and may dismiss the relevance of research to their practice (Cameron & Este, 2008). Journal clubs have been identified as a way of helping students and practitioners to become more confident in appraising research and to help show how research can inform practice (Moore et al., 2013). Using a journal club as an assessment task is informed by research on social work education that suggests that hands-on activities (Lei, 2008) and peer learning (Pan & Tang, 2005; Wilson, 2006, 2008) can reduce student anxiety and support learning about research.

Task Description

In your group (3–4 members), facilitate a 25 or 30-minute journal discussion with the class, based on your appraisal of research papers on a shared topic.

For this task some elements of the task attract an individual mark and others related to group facilitation will receive a group mark. Please check the marking rubric on Blackboard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This description is only a summary of the task. For full details, including the marking rubric, please refer to the course Learn UQ (Blackboard) site.

Rationale

As you will learn in this course, a research proposal is a structured document that explains what you plan to research, why it’s important, and how you plan to investigate it. As a social worker, you may need to draft a research proposal in order to undertake practice-based research within your organisation, apply for grants/funding, or as part of future study or an academic career!

Task Description

In the exam, you will be provided with a brief AI generated literature review related to a particular social work research problem.

You will be required to critique the AI generated literature review. You will then use the literature review as a stimulus to develop a research proposal that outlines the details of a research project that would help to address the identified knowledge gap.

The exam will be a series of short answer questions that mirror the elements of a research proposal.

Your responses must demonstrate engagement with and understanding of the SWSP3303 course material.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Why does social work research matter?

Welcome to SWSP3303!

Please make sure you work through the week 1 online module on Blackboard before you attend this, our first workshop.

In the workshop, we will begin by introducing the course and assessment. We will then do activities that build on and apply the material from the week 1 online module.

We conclude the session with your first of six (1/6) in-class quizzes (10mins; 3-4 questions; 4% of total grade). It will assess your understanding of material from the required readings, online material and workshop for this week's content. Remember - only the best 5 scores out of the 6 quizzes will be counted towards your total mark for this assessment item.

Learning outcomes: L01, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Frameworks underpinning social work research

Please make sure you work through the week 2 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

This week, we will do activities that build on and apply the material from the week 2 online modules. For example, we will consider how different research paradigms can alter the way we approach research on the same topic.

We conclude the session with your second of six (2/6) in-class quizzes (10mins; 3-4 questions; 4% of total grade). It will assess your understanding of material from the required readings, online material and workshop for this week's content.

Remember - only the best 5 scores out of the 6 quizzes will be counted towards your total mark for this assessment item.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: How to conduct a literature review

Please make sure you work through the week 3 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

This week, we will do activities that build on and apply the material from the week 3 online modules. This will involve a library session on search strategies.

We conclude the session with your second of six (3/6) in-class quizzes (10mins; 3-4 questions; 4% of total grade). It will assess your understanding of material from the required readings, online material and workshop for this week's content.

Remember - only the best 5 scores out of the 6 quizzes will be counted towards your total mark for this assessment item.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Developing your research question

Please make sure you work through the week 4 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

This week, we will do activities that build on and apply the material from the week 4 online module. These activities will help you identify the research gap and craft an answerable research question.

We also introduce the concept and format of a 'Journal Club' to help get you ready for assessment task 2.

We conclude the session with your fourth of six (4/6) in-class quizzes (10mins; 3-4 questions; 4% of total grade). It will assess your understanding of material from the required readings, online material and workshop for this week's content.

Remember - only the best 5 scores out of the 6 quizzes will be counted towards your total mark for this assessment item.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: What to consider when designing your research

Please make sure you work through the week 5 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

This week, we will do activities that build on and apply the material from the week 5 online module. These activities will help further your understanding of different research designs.

We continue to learn about Journal Clubs. We'll introduce you to the marking rubric for assessment 2 and you'll be asked to apply it to a 'not so good' example of a journal club. We'll then work together to identify how it could have been better. This will help you and your group with your preparations for your own Journal Club session!

We conclude the session with your fifth of six (5/6) in-class quizzes (10mins; 3-4 questions; 4% of total grade). It will assess your understanding of material from the required readings, online material and workshop for this week's content.

Remember - only the best 5 scores out of the 6 quizzes will be counted towards your total mark for this assessment item.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Sampling - Where should you get your data from?

Please make sure you work through the week 6 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

This week, we will do activities that build on and apply the material from the week 6 online module. These activities will help further your understanding of different approaches to sampling.

We continue to learn about Journal Clubs. Again, we'll use the marking rubric for assessment 2 to assess an example of a Journal Club session. We'll then work together to identify how it could have been better. This will help you and your group with your preparations for your own Journal Club session!

We conclude the session with your last (6/6) in-class quiz (10mins; 3-4 questions; 4% of total grade). It will assess your understanding of material from the required readings, online material and workshop for this week's content.

Remember - only the best 5 scores out of the 6 quizzes will be counted towards your total mark for this assessment item.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Words Part 1 - How to collect qualitative data

Please make sure you work through the week 7 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

We are shifting up the formats of the workshops for the next few weeks as we are entering our Journal Club era!

So, we'll begin the session with group Journal Club presentations (based on the previous week's content - sampling). Given that there are marks for facilitating group discussion, please come and support your peers, even if it is not your week to present.

We'll then undertake some applied activities related to the content in this week's online learning materials about collecting qualitative data.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

Again, we'll begin the session with group Journal Club presentations on qualitative data collection.

We'll then undertake some applied activities related to the content in this week's online learning materials about analysing qualitative data.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

Please make sure you work through the week 9 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

We'll then undertake some applied activities related to the content in this week's online learning materials about collecting quantitative data.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: How to share your findings with different audiences

Please make sure you work through the week 11 online module on Blackboard before you attend our workshop this week.

In this workshop we will look at examples of different research dissemination strategies and consider their audience and purpose. You'll then work in groups to develop a dissemination strategy for different stakeholders.

Depending on the number of students enrolled in the course, we may also have another round of Journal Club presentations this week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

You'll then work in groups to develop a dissemination strategy for different stakeholders. Depending on the number of students enrolled in the course, we may also have another round of Journal Club presentations this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Bringing it all together in a research proposal

This week we bring everything you've learnt so far in the course together and talk about research proposals.

There are a few resources listed on your Blackboard site.

We'll look at more 'good' and 'not so good' examples of research proposals. We are doing this to help you to prepare for your final exam.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Exam preparation

There is no online material this week.

Our workshop will be completely dedicated to exam preparation, so please join us!

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
